stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, two minutes after induction of anaesthesia for an elective procedure, the patient develops severe hypotension, bronchospasm, and an urticarial rash. What is your diagnosis and immediate management?

expectedKeyFacts: Diagnose anaphylaxis: clinical triad of cardiovascular collapse, bronchospasm, rash
Stop suspected trigger — likely NMBA, antibiotic, or latex
Call for help
100% oxygen, secure airway if needed
Adrenaline 50 mcg IV boluses (0.5 mL of 1:10,000) titrated to response
Or IM adrenaline 500 mcg (0.5 mL of 1:1000) if no IV access
Start IV fluid resuscitation — 500-1000 mL crystalloid bolus
Lie flat, elevate legs

prompts.text: The patient remains hypotensive and bronchospastic despite initial adrenaline. What further measures would you take?
expectedKeyFacts: Repeat adrenaline 50-100 mcg IV boluses every 1-2 minutes
Consider adrenaline infusion if repeated boluses needed (0.05-0.5 mcg/kg/min)
Aggressive fluid resuscitation — may need several litres
Salbutamol for persistent bronchospasm — nebulised or IV
Chlorphenamine 10 mg IV
Hydrocortisone 200 mg IV — prevents biphasic reaction
Arterial line for BP monitoring
Consider ICU transfer

prompts.text: What investigations would you send during and after the event?
expectedKeyFacts: During: mast cell tryptase at time of reaction, then 1-2 hours, then 24 hours
Peak tryptase 1-2 hours post-reaction
Baseline tryptase >24 hours after reaction
Elevated tryptase confirms mast cell degranulation
Specific IgE testing at 6 weeks in allergy clinic
Skin prick testing at 4-6 weeks
Identify culprit drug for future avoidance
Document in notes and alert patient

prompts.text: Why is adrenaline the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis?
expectedKeyFacts: α1-agonist: vasoconstriction — reverses vasodilation and hypotension
β1-agonist: positive inotropy and chronotropy — improves cardiac output
β2-agonist: bronchodilation — reverses bronchospasm
Stabilises mast cells — reduces further mediator release
No other drug has all these combined effects
IV route allows rapid titration in anaesthetised patients
IM route safer in non-monitored settings (community, wards)
Delay in adrenaline associated with worse outcomes

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me about the dose and route of adrenaline in anaphylaxis — how much would you give and how?
keyFacts: Clinical features: hypotension, bronchospasm, urticaria, angioedema
Stop trigger, call for help, 100% oxygen
Adrenaline 50 mcg IV (0.5 mL 1:10,000) or 500 mcg IM (0.5 mL 1:1,000)
Mast cell tryptase: at event, 1-2 hours, 24 hours
Follow-up: allergy clinic, skin prick testing at 4-6 weeks
Common triggers: NMBAs, antibiotics, latex, chlorhexidine

scoringGuidance.pass: Diagnoses anaphylaxis promptly, knows correct adrenaline dose and route, describes escalation strategy including infusion, mentions fluid resuscitation and adjuncts, understands tryptase testing timeline, explains adrenaline's mechanism; stronger candidates discuss biphasic reactions and allergy follow-up pathway
scoringGuidance.borderline: Recognises anaphylaxis but dose/route of adrenaline unclear, mentions some adjuncts but management not systematic, vague on investigations or follow-up
scoringGuidance.fail: Does not diagnose anaphylaxis or delays recognition, incorrect adrenaline dose or route, no systematic approach, unaware of tryptase testing or allergy referral
